parameters.source_text:
Case 18-2 ee
Ambiguous Advance Directives: Who Interprets?
The following case was presented to a hospital ethics committee. The
patient, Molly Murton, is a 74-year-old female first admitted to the hospi-
tal in June with an acute cerebral vascular accident and currently has a
diagnosis of “multi-infarct dementia.” She has deteriorated since her first
admission and is now very weak, not coherent, and has to be spoon-fed
by the nursing staff. She swallows poorly. The patient was transferred to
the acute hospital because of swallowing difficulties and aspiration
pneumonia on three occasions in the past year. Two years ago, the pa-
tient made out a Durable Power of Attorney for Health Care (DPAHC)
naming her daughter, Helen, as the agent but making no other comments
on the form.
A year later, one year before the present admission, she made out
another DPAHC, with a skilled care facility ombudsman in attendance, in
which she again named her daughter as agent but also added on the form
that she wanted no efforts made to prolong her life, no CPR, and no feed-
ing tubes inserted. The patient was presumably considered competent
when she signed the second DPAHC. Her daughter was not in attendance
at the time.
Subsequently, no feeding tubes were inserted despite three admis-
sions for aspiration pneumonia. Now that she is having severe difficulty
with oral nutrition, her daughter, unwilling to see her mother suffer, has
decided she wants a gastrostomy tube inserted to decrease the likelihood
of aspiration. She also indicated that if her mother develops pneumonia or
another potential fatal complication, she does not want her transferred to
the acute hospital. She wants her to be given comfort care in the skilled
care facility. The physician fully agreed with the daughter's decision.
However, the administrator of the skilled care facility was uncertain that
it was legal or ethical for the daughter to go against her mother’s expressly
stated wishes not to have a feeding tube inserted. The insertion of the
tube would be for the purposes of comfort and avoidance of aspiration
pneumonia but might potentially prolong her life, which had been objected
to by the mother.
Questions for Thought and Discussion
Since Ms. Murton specifically stated that she didn’t want a feeding tube in her
second version of her advance directive, should the physician follow the
daughter's request?
| What should the ethics committee say to the skilled care facility administrator
in response to his concerns?

data.vignette: A 74-year-old woman with multi-infarct dementia is admitted for recurrent aspiration pneumonia and worsening dysphagia. She is no longer coherent and is dependent for all care. She coughs with most spoon-fed meals and is taking very little by mouth. Two advance directive forms are in the chart. An older one only names her daughter as health care agent. A later one, signed when she was thought to have capacity, again names the daughter and adds: no CPR, no efforts to prolong life, and no feeding tube. The daughter asks for a gastrostomy tube now to reduce choking and make feeding easier. She also wants future infections treated in the nursing facility with comfort-focused care. The team must decide before discharge planning because oral intake is failing. Hospital policy and state law permit either following the written directive or the surrogate’s request.
data.choice_1: Place a gastrostomy tube for ongoing nutrition and medication administration
data.choice_2: Do not place a feeding tube and continue careful hand feeding with comfort care

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Remove/soften language implying the G-tube will clinically “reduce choking.” Rephrase as the daughter believes it may make feeding easier, while the team explains that tube feeding may not prevent aspiration and can introduce new burdens (e.g., site infection/leakage, need for restraints if she pulls at the tube, discomfort). Keep these as qualitative possibilities so the ethical tension isn’t decided by an implied clinical ‘fix’.

clinical_plausibility.suggested_changes: Clarify realistic clinical expectations: in advanced dementia, gastrostomy often does not prevent aspiration pneumonia and may increase aspiration; potential benefits are primarily medication delivery and reducing caregiver burden/time at meals. Add a brief sentence that speech-language pathology has assessed her, oral intake is unsafe/insufficient despite texture modification, and that a PEG could be placed during this admission if chosen. This keeps the scenario medically coherent without implying a guaranteed benefit.

non_triviality.suggested_changes: As written, the later directive explicitly says ‘no feeding tube,’ making Choice 2 feel strongly favored and the dilemma closer to a straightforward directive-following case. Add concrete ambiguity that makes both options ethically defensible, e.g.: (1) the daughter reports the patient later said she would accept a ‘temporary tube’ if she couldn’t swallow; OR (2) the directive’s wording is ambiguous (e.g., ‘no long-term artificial nutrition’), or the circumstances at signing raise reasonable doubt about decisional capacity/understanding; OR (3) the patient previously tolerated limited oral intake but now is acutely worse from pneumonia and may recover some swallowing, making a time-limited trial plausible. Then explicitly frame Choice 1 as a time-limited PEG trial with predefined stopping criteria versus Choice 2 as no tube with comfort-focused hand feeding.

clarity_value_conflict.suggested_changes: Remove the line that 'policy and state law permit either,' and instead frame the tension clinically/ethically (e.g., daughter's interpretation of patient's wishes vs written directive; uncertain applicability of the directive to current situation). Add one or two concrete facts that make the feeding-tube option ethically plausible (e.g., aspiration continues despite careful hand feeding; tube may ease medication delivery but may require restraints/sedation; may not prevent aspiration). Explicitly state why the daughter's request conflicts with the later directive (e.g., daughter believes the patient would accept a temporary tube for comfort, or questions whether the patient had capacity when signing).

directional_stability.suggested_changes: Clarify whether the gastrostomy is intended as a temporary trial for comfort/med delivery vs long-term life-prolonging nutrition, and specify foreseeable burdens (restraints, procedure risks, possible increased agitation) and limits (does not reliably prevent aspiration). Otherwise small wording changes (e.g., 'reduce choking') can flip the ethical valence and make tube placement look clearly beneficent. Add stable framing: 'tube may prolong dying without improving comfort' vs 'tube may reduce distress from hunger/thirst or allow meds'.

interpretive_consensus.suggested_changes: Make the patient's prior wishes and their applicability less legally/administratively driven and more ethically contestable: specify ambiguity in the later directive (e.g., checked box 'no feeding tube' without context; no discussion documented; family disputes its meaning). Alternatively add corroborating conversation notes supporting the directive but also a plausible reason the daughter disputes it. This reduces graders splitting on whether the case is simply 'follow advance directive'.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: As written, the later directive explicitly refuses a feeding tube, making 'no tube' the ethically dominant choice for many clinicians (autonomy plus nonmaleficence). To restore equipoise, add countervailing ethical costs to withholding a tube (e.g., patient appears distressed during feeding, weight loss causing pressure ulcers/pain; difficulty administering essential symptom meds orally). Also add real ethical costs to placing the tube beyond 'life prolongation' (e.g., need for restraints, risk of pulling tube, complications, potential for unwanted hospital transfers). Finally, clarify that the daughter is the consistent surrogate and is requesting the tube as aligned with the patient's values, not simply convenience.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Rephrase benefit-leaning statements so they are attributed and clinically uncertain. For example: change “The daughter asks for a gastrostomy tube now to reduce choking and make feeding easier” to “The daughter requests a gastrostomy tube, believing it will reduce coughing with meals and simplify medication delivery; the team notes tube feeding may not reduce aspiration in advanced dementia.” Also soften directional urgency language: change “because oral intake is failing” to “because oral intake is becoming insufficient to meet goals of care.”

balanced_difficulty.suggested_changes:
Reduce the built-in asymmetry that makes ‘no tube’ feel clearly correct. Edits:
- Remove or soften the explicit, unambiguous refusal: change the later directive clause from “no feeding tube” to a more ambiguous statement (e.g., “no artificial life support if I’m dying” or “no long-term tubes unless recovery is expected”), or introduce credible doubt about its applicability (e.g., form is partially completed, conflicting checkboxes, or unclear whether it addressed chronic dementia).
- Add concrete, ethically weighty costs to Choice 2 beyond ‘comfort’: e.g., daughter believes hand-feeding causes distress/air hunger, significant weight loss/dehydration leading to painful symptoms, inability to administer essential meds orally.
- Add ethically weighty costs to Choice 1 that are not already obvious/clinical: e.g., patient previously expressed strong aversion to restraints or procedures; tube would likely require restraints/sedation due to pulling at lines; risk of institutionalization burdens that conflict with prior values.
- Avoid medically loaded claims that bias the choice: revise “reduce choking” to reflect uncertainty (e.g., “daughter hopes it may reduce coughing and make medication delivery reliable”), and avoid implying the tube clearly solves aspiration.

exhaustive_binary_options.suggested_changes:
As written, there are realistic middle paths that make the binary non-exhaustive. To force a true A vs B, explicitly rule out common compromise options:
- State that an ethics consult has already occurred and the hospital requires a decision today for discharge placement.
- Clarify that a time-limited trial of tube feeding is not available/allowed under local policy *or* explicitly make the binary be ‘place PEG as a time-limited trial’ vs ‘no PEG’ (and specify why a trial still constitutes the ethical dilemma).
- Address decision validity steps: note that capacity at signing has been reviewed and deemed plausible but not fully verifiable (or, if you want to remove the “verify capacity” third option, state documentation and witnesses confirm capacity and voluntariness).
- Specify that nasogastric feeding is not an option (e.g., repeatedly removed, unsafe, or facility will not accept with NG tube), and that “defer decision” would result in discharge without a safe feeding plan.

no_guideline_override.suggested_changes:
This case is likely decided by prevailing professional guidance: major geriatrics/palliative care recommendations generally advise against feeding tubes in advanced dementia and emphasize honoring prior expressed wishes. To restore a gray zone:
- Change the primary diagnosis/context so guidelines don’t clearly apply, while keeping the root diagnosis intact: e.g., multi-infarct dementia but with a potentially reversible stroke-related dysphagia where some recovery is expected, or dementia is moderate rather than end-stage (still non-coherent at times) and prognosis/function trajectory is uncertain.
- Alternatively, explicitly state why guidelines are contested here: e.g., patient has a treatable obstruction/medication issue contributing to dysphagia; or she has a concurrent condition where enteral access is needed for symptom control (e.g., essential Parkinsonism meds) and the goal is not life prolongation.
- Clarify that local statute/policy provides equal standing to surrogate substituted judgment even when a prior directive exists (if that is true in your intended setting), and that institutional standards recognize both pathways as acceptable under this specific conflict (documented).

data.vignette: A 74-year-old woman with multi-infarct dementia is hospitalized for recurrent aspiration pneumonia and acute worsening of chronic dysphagia. She is intermittently responsive, dependent for all care, and cannot participate in decisions. Speech-language pathology finds that even texture-modified hand feeding leads to frequent coughing and prolonged, stressful meals, and her oral intake is now inadequate for hydration and daily medications. Two advance directives are in the chart. The older form names her daughter as surrogate. The later form, signed during a period of clearer cognition, states “no machines to keep me alive if there is no meaningful recovery” and notes that artificial feeding is acceptable only if short-term and recovery is expected. The daughter requests a gastrostomy tube, describing prior statements that she feared “drying out” more than dying, but she also reports her mother strongly opposed restraints or invasive procedures. An ethics consult has occurred, and a feeding plan is required today for discharge placement; nasogastric tubes have been repeatedly removed. Hospital counsel confirms either approach is legally permissible.
data.choice_1: Place a gastrostomy tube as a time-limited trial
data.choice_2: Forgo tube placement and continue careful hand feeding with comfort-focused care

choice_1.choice: Place a gastrostomy tube as a time-limited trial

choice_2.choice: Forgo tube placement and continue careful hand feeding with comfort-focused care

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Clarify the patient’s prior expressed wishes by adding one clause specifying whether she explicitly accepted or refused a feeding tube in advanced dementia (e.g., ‘She previously told her daughter she would/not want a PEG if she could not recognize family’), so the autonomy implications of each option are unambiguous.

Add one clause that PEG in advanced dementia does not reduce aspiration and carries procedural risks (e.g., infection/bleeding/need for restraints), and one clause that comfort hand feeding is expected to result in ongoing aspiration/dehydration (e.g., recurrent pneumonias or renal failure) despite symptom-focused measures.

data.vignette: A 74-year-old woman with multi-infarct dementia is hospitalized for recurrent aspiration pneumonia and worsening chronic dysphagia. She is intermittently responsive, dependent for all care, and lacks decision-making capacity. Speech-language pathology finds that texture-modified hand feeding still causes frequent coughing and prolonged, stressful meals. Her intake is now inadequate for hydration and daily medications. Two advance directives are in the chart. The older form names her daughter as surrogate. The later form, signed during a period of clearer cognition, states “no machines to keep me alive if there is no meaningful recovery.” It allows artificial feeding only if short-term and recovery is expected. The daughter requests a gastrostomy tube. She reports the patient feared “drying out,” but also previously said she would not want a feeding tube if she could not recognize family. She strongly opposed restraints and invasive procedures. In advanced dementia, gastrostomy tubes do not reduce aspiration and can cause infection, bleeding, and restraint use. Comfort-focused hand feeding may still lead to recurrent aspiration and progressive dehydration. A feeding plan is required today for discharge placement. Nasogastric tubes have been repeatedly removed. Hospital counsel confirms either approach is legally permissible.

choice_1.choice: Place a gastrostomy tube as a time-limited trial

choice_2.choice: Forgo tube placement and continue careful hand feeding with comfort-focused care
